awd_titl_txt: SBP:  Workshop:  Expanding Linguistic Science By Broadening Native American Participation
awd_abstract_narration:
The Native American Languages Act, passed by the U.S. Congress in 1990, enacted into policy the recognition of the unique status and importance of Native American languages. Similarly, the field of linguistics emphasizes the importance of Native American languages, not only because of languages' intrinsic value as bearers of culture and identity, but also with reference to scientific questions whose answers lie in the diverse grammatical features, vocabularies, and usage patterns of these languages. Less recognized, however, is that there is an equally important and similarly diverse set of ideas held in Native American communities about their languages -- ideas that reflect Native American intellectual traditions, cultural norms, and contemporary needs. This project focuses on identifying, disseminating, and applying Native American ideas about language in linguistic science through a workshop at which American Indian and Alaska Native language practitioners (e.g., citizen scientists, language program coordinators, educators, language activists) and professional linguists will engage in dialogue about these issues. This project will thus test a model of expanding science through the participation of an underrepresented group in a way that emphasizes the intellectual tools and cultural values of that group, contributing to the science of broadening participation. The ideas from this project will be widely disseminated, with project presentations and other materials shared online and archived for others' use. Broader impacts also include the increased participation of Native Americans in the language sciences, the development and training of non-Native graduate students, and the online dissemination of workshop outcomes, videos and content through the Linguistic Society of America, the largest professional society in the world dedicated to the scientific study of language. 

Co-chaired by two Native American linguists, this workshop will improve linguistic science by fostering a scholarly space to explore and to expand the intellectual lens through which the goals, questions and methods of linguistics are framed. Through a collaborative model in which people who have shared interests but different types of expertise train each other, this project seeks to increase the representation of Native Americans in language sciences through an approach that puts Native American colleagues on equal footing with colleagues from other backgrounds. Motivating this project is a general question of how to apply linguistic diversity, broadly defined to include views about language, as a base to guide and expand scientific inquiry. Its specific focus on Native American ideas about language emerges from the shared commitment of the U.S. Congress, the field of linguistics, and Native American communities to promoting Native American languages. The workshop will occur immediately prior to the 2018 annual meeting of the Linguistic Society of America, the premier professional conference of American linguists. The project team will select workshop participants through a competitive application process; selection criteria will include documented expertise in, and commitment to, project themes. The workshop will include a lecture to contextualize the history of linguistics and its current areas of focus, a session in which participants share their personal definitions of "language," and several collaborative discussions on core project themes. Workshop participants will then attend the rest of the Linguistic Society of America annual meeting, which will include a symposium to share the ideas that emerge from the workshop with a large audience of linguists.

por.por_cntn:
Despite its robust record of research on Native American languages, the discipline called Linguistics has historically not engaged the intellectual traditions and ethics of knowledge production that come from Native American language communities. Co-chaired by two Native American linguists, the Expanding Linguistic Science By Broadening Native American Participation project was created in response to this shortcoming. Its primary intellectual objective was to expand, and thereby improve, the field of Linguistics by identifying, valorizing, and integrating Native American ways of defining "language" and protocols of engaging in language research. A closely related goal was to address the severe underrepresentation of Native Americans in language sciences by responding to a recurring pattern wherein Native Americans report negative experiences when they pursue linguistics training.

The project's central activity was a satellite workshop held in conjunction with the 92nd Annual Meeting of the Linguistic Society of America (LSA), which took place in Salt Lake City from January 4-7, 2018. Following a competitive application process with over 100 applicants from the United States and Canada, the workshop brought together 48 scholars whose work centers Native American language communities, 28 of whom were themselves members of these communities. Intentionally set up to occur at the primary professional gathering of linguists in the United States, the satellite workshop was predicated on a model of taking Native American ideas to the discipline of Linguistics, rather than taking the discipline in its current form to Native Americans. The underlying theory guiding the concept of broadening Native American participation was that when the discipline of Linguistics better includes and respects Native American needs, views, and contributions to science, more Native American scholars will follow. The project's informal name, Natives4Linguistics, reflects this orientation. "Natives," adopted for this project as an umbrella term for the American Indian, Alaska Native, First Nations, Metis, Inuit, and Native Hawaiian community members that the workshop included, comes first. The non-standard spelling of the project's name symbolically represents the importance of questioning, and where appropriate providing alternatives to, dominant disciplinary assumptions and objectives.

The satellite workshop had three main components. The first was an all-day session for the 48 selected participants on identifying and integrating Native American definitions of language into linguistic science. A central finding was that Native American communities' definitions of "language" are largely relational (centered around relationships with lands, communities, and histories) and often existentially important to those communities (central to their peoplehood), but rarely drawn upon for purposes of describing and analyzing language in scientific contexts. For instance, participants discussed how scientific publications that report on Native American languages often barely even mention these relations, and they called for change. The second component was a symposium which featured a subset of Natives4Linguistics participants presenting about Native American approaches to "language" and theorizing the ways in which these approaches can inform scientific inquiry and disciplinary practice. Occurring in the middle of the larger LSA conference and open to all, this symposium was one of the mechanisms by which the project realized its goal of taking Native American views to a wide array of linguists. Third, there was a debriefing meeting on the final day of the LSA conference where the 48 participants, who had participated in the whole conference, regrouped to discuss what they had observed and to plan for the future. This debriefing meeting, which included officers and staff of the LSA, served as the start of a series of follow-up actions and consultations to address the gaps that project participants had observed. There was also a call for a permanent Natives4Linguistics special interest group within the LSA, which was developed over the following year and formally approved by the LSA Executive Committee in 2019. In addition to serving as a conduit to take Native American needs and ideas to the broader community of linguists, this special interest group supports events, training, and mentoring to further Natives4Linguistics goals and capacity building.

By showing how Native American intellectual traditions and cultural norms can be employed to do linguistic work, this project has effected positive change in linguistic research and teaching, and cultivated a network of scholars to continue work with these aims. In addition to the publications that resulted within the project period (with others in development as of the project's end), there were also several presentations and workshops to promote Natives4Linguistics ideas and findings, thereby extending the project's reach. Meanwhile, the project, which intentionally included community- and university-based scholars at a variety of levels, also supported the professional development and advancement for many of its participants. For instance, the project PI/co-chair earned tenure, the other co-chair completed a PhD in Linguistics and assumed a tenure-track position, and additional participants completed degrees and gained professional employment in language sciences.
